user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_ip_addr_to_key:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
MHD_ip_addr_to_key (const struct sockaddr_storage *addr,
                    socklen_t addrlen,
                    struct MHD_IPCount *key)
{
  memset (key,
          0,
          sizeof(*key));

  /* IPv4 addresses */
  if (sizeof (struct sockaddr_in) <= (size_t) addrlen)
  {
    if (AF_INET == addr->ss_family)
    {
      key->family = AF_INET;
      memcpy (&key->addr.ipv4,
              &((const struct sockaddr_in *) addr)->sin_addr,
              sizeof(((const struct sockaddr_in *) NULL)->sin_addr));
      return MHD_YES;
    }
  }

#ifdef HAVE_INET6
  if (sizeof (struct sockaddr_in6) <= (size_t) addrlen)
  {
    /* IPv6 addresses */
    if (AF_INET6 == addr->ss_family)
    {
      key->family = AF_INET6;
      memcpy (&key->addr.ipv6,
              &((const struct sockaddr_in6 *) addr)->sin6_addr,
              sizeof(((const struct sockaddr_in6 *) NULL)->sin6_addr));
      return MHD_YES;
    }
  }
#endif

  /* Some other address */
  return MHD_NO;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No function parameter is modified in the sense prohibited by MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8. Details:
- addr (const struct sockaddr_storage *): only inspected (ss_family) and cast for memcpy source; no assignment to addr, no increment/decrement, no storing through addr. The casts and use in sizeof do not modify the parameter.
- addrlen (socklen_t): only used in comparisons (no assignment or modification).
- key (struct MHD_IPCount *): the object pointed-to by key is written (memset, field assignments, memcpy). MISRA Rule 17.8 allows modifying the object referred to by a pointer parameter; the prohibition is against modifying the pointer parameter itself. There is no assignment to the pointer variable key (no rebind of key), so this is permitted.
- Other expressions (sizeof(((const struct sockaddr_in *) NULL)->sin_addr), casting to struct sockaddr_in6) are compile-time/evaluation-safe and do not modify parameters.
Therefore there are no code fragments that violate Rule 17.8 and nothing that requires further investigation for this rule.
